com.analog.lyric.dimple.model.domains

Class DiscreteDomain

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.analog.lyric.dimple.model.domains.Domain
      • com.analog.lyric.dimple.model.domains.DiscreteDomain
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    java.io.Serializable
    Direct Known Subclasses:
    TypedDiscreteDomain

    @Immutable
public abstract class DiscreteDomain
extends Domain
    Domain for discrete variables that can take on a values from a predefined finite set in a specified order.

    While from a set-theoretic perspective two domains with the same elements in different order are equivalent, these objects are only considered equal if the elements occur in the same order because the order is intrinsic in the representation of variable values using the domain.

    See Also:
    Serialized Form

      • range

        public static IntRangeDomain range(int low,
                   int high)
        Returns discrete domain containing all integers from low to high.
        Parameters:
        low - is the first element of the domain
        high - is the last element of the domain, which must be greater than or equal to low
        See Also:
        range(int, int, int)

      • range

        public static IntRangeDomain range(int low,
                   int high,
                   int interval)
        Returns discrete domain containing all integers from low to high in increments of specified interval.

        Parameters:
        low - is the first element of the domain
        high - is the upper bound of the domain, which must be greater than low. Will only be included in the domain itself if (high - low) is a multiple of interval.
        interval - is a positive integer specifying the increment between adjacent elements in the domain.
        See Also:
        range(int, int)

      • range

        public boolean equals(@Nullable
             java.lang.Object thatObj)
        True if elements of domain are the same and in the same order.

        The default implementation simply does an elementwise comparison.

      • getElement

        public abstract java.lang.Object getElement(int i)
        Returns the value of the ith element in the domain.
        Parameters:
        i - must be in the range [0,size()-1].

      • getElements

        public java.lang.Object[] getElements()
        Returns an array containing all the elements of the domain in their canonical order.

        Because this allocates memory and costs linear time to compute, it is usually better to use getElement(int) to access elements one at a time and size() to get the number of elements.

        See Also:
        getElements(Object[])

      • getElements

        public <T> T[] getElements(@Nullable
                  T[] array)
        Returns an array containing all of the elements of the domain in their canonical order using provided array if possible.

        If array has a component type compatible with getElementClass() and length at least as large as size() it will be filled in with the domain elements and returned. If array has a compatible type but is not long enough, a new array will be returned with the same component type as array. Otherwise a new array will be returned with component type same as getElementClass().

      • size

        public abstract int size()
        The number of elements in the domain.

      • getIndexOrThrow
